III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was able to hang himself while under staff supervision
outlined in a safety plan.
Investigation On 8/12/24 DCWL was notified by Community Mental Health that
Youth A was hospitalized on 8/9/24 as he was able to hang
himself in the presence of staff. There was concern that Youth A
had a safety plan for increased supervision, due to multiple trips to
the emergency room, yet was able to self-harm. The hospital
denied access to agency social worker to obtain an update.
On 8/14/24, DCWL received notification that Youth A attempted to
self-harm again on 8/13/24, after he was released from the
hospital. Youth A was then taken back to the hospital under
inpatient care, with plans to discharge to a secure facility.
Interviews:
Clinical Director contacted DCWL via email on 8/12/24. Clinical
Director reported that Youth A attempted to hang himself around
6:00PM, outside of the cottage. Police and ambulance were
contacted, and Youth A was transported to the hospital for an
evaluation. Clinical Director was then interviewed face-to-face by
DCWL and MDHHS Worker on 8/13/24. Clinical Director reported
that on 8/9/24 Youth A asked to make a call during dinner time.
Staff and other youth were still eating. Staff told Youth A to wait for
a few minutes, then he could make his call. Youth A escalated
and began throwing things. Management and crisis team were
contacted to assist. The crisis team consists of case managers
and a behavioral specialist. Law Enforcement was also contacted.
When the crisis team arrived, Youth A was in the cottage,
attempting to self-harm. Youth A had a history of using clothing to
put around his neck, then loop over a door. Staff attempted to
remove items from Youth A’s possession at various times,
2

including a hair straightener cord, pants, and a blanket. Youth A
had some marks on his neck from items rubbing as staff removed
them. Law Enforcement transported Youth A to the hospital.
Youth A was not on 1:1 supervision at that time. 1:1 supervision
has since been requested from DHHS. A 30-day notice was
provided to DHHS on 5/30/24. Youth A has had several incidents
of attempted self-harm and indicates he continues this behavior as
he wants to move. The clinical team meets twice weekly to review
his needs. The current safety plan is heightened supervision, and
that staff are aware of Youth A's triggers and behaviors.
Youth B was interviewed fact-to-face on 8/13/24 by DCWL and
MDHHS Worker. Youth B was present during the alleged incident
on 8/9/24. Youth B stated that he observed Youth A take
belongings from Youth B’s cubby. Youth A used Youth B’s pants,
wrapped them around his neck and tried to put them over a door.
Staff were with him, following him and trying to talk to him. Staff
attempted to get the item from Youth A, but Youth A would run
away. When staff were able to get the pants away from Youth A,
he grabbed a flat iron out of Youth B’s cubby and attempted to use
the cord to hang himself. Staff chased Youth A and were able to
get the flat iron from Youth A.
Youth B stated that everything happened outside his door, which
is why he was able to see it all. Youth B felt that Youth A was
“playing” the whole time. Youth B stated that Youth A smiled at
him. Youth B stated that Youth A tries to self-harm when he wants
something, because he feels he will get what he wants. Youth B
stated he has also done this behavior and discussed it with Youth
A. Youth B never heard Youth A state he really wanted to harm
himself. Youth B did not have any concerns about staff and stated
they are fair and take care of kids.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face on 8/13/24 by DCWL and
MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported she was present for the incident
on 8/9/24. The group was eating dinner when Youth A asked Staff
2 to let him make a phone call. Staff 2 told Youth A that he needed
to wait for about five minutes, until dinner was done. Youth A got
upset, threw staff’s food, threw clothing and furniture around the
unit. Youth A made verbal threats to beat up staff. Youth A then
grabbed a blanket and tried to tie it around his neck. Staff followed
Youth A, encouraging him to stop his behavior. Youth A went to
the exit door and tried to throw the end of the blanket over the
automatic closure device. Staff stopped him and removed the
blanket. Youth A then grabbed a hot iron from a peer’s cubby and
put the cord around his neck. Staff again encouraged him to take
3

the cord off. Youth A tried to put the cord over the door, but was
unsuccessful, as staff were talking with him and able to remove
the item. Youth A was never hanging.
Previously Youth A has used pieces of wood from outside, or
plastic pieces he’s broken off items, and threatened to cut himself.
Typically, Youth A will make the verbal threat, but never act on it.
Youth A’s safety plan is to have staff sit outside of his door during
sleeping hours and have increased supervision during awake
hours. Staff are aware that Youth A needs to be supervised at all
times. Staff did not attempt to restrain during incidents due to
Youth A’s size and concern it would further escalate him. Staff
have been successful at preventing Youth A from harming himself
through discussion and monitoring. Staff 1 indicated she did not
believe Youth A really wanted to hurt himself. Youth A stated
several times that he hated being there and wanted to leave.
Case Manager was interviewed face-to-face on 8/15/24 by DCWL
and MDHHS Worker. Case Manager reported the clinical review
team meets every day to discuss Youth A. The agency was
advocating for an inpatient program. Case Manager
acknowledged it was difficult to limit Youth A’s access to outdoors
or other areas, due to being a non-secure program. Youth A would
search for other people’s belongings to use to attempt self-harm
or Youth A would threaten to take his own clothing off and use it to
self-harm. Case Manager stated Youth A is a great kid, but
struggles with impulsive behavior, which they continue to work on.
Case Manager was not present for the incident on 8/9/24, but
reported she was aware of what occurred. Staff at the facility are
certified in TCI. However, they did not restrain Youth A throughout
the incident as they felt he was not at imminent risk, and they
were able to prevent him from self-harm. Case Manager was
present for the incident on 8/13/24 as she walked into the unit and
saw Youth A with the curtains around his neck. Youth A was
standing on a shelf under the window, to reach the curtains. Staff
were standing on a couch to reach the curtains and cut them
down. Law Enforcement arrived 5-10 minutes after the curtains
were cut. Youth A was never hanging or suspended. Youth A was
standing on two feet the entire time. Case Manager was confident
the curtain rod would not have held his weight if he tried to get off
his feet. Case Manager observed staff to be verbally supportive
and manage the environment throughout the incident. Youth A
was laughing and smiling. Youth A grabbed a towel and before he
could do anything, Case Manager was able to grab the towel from
him. Youth A laughed and stated, “You’re f***ing fast. How’d you
4

catch me?” Youth A has stated repeatedly that he wants to leave
the program.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face on 8/15/24 by DCWL
and MDHHS Worker. Supervisor 1 reported they were present for
the 8/9/24 incident. Supervisor 1 arrived on the unit after
Supervisor 2 called for support. When Supervisor 1 arrived on the
unit, staff were attempting to get Youth A to remove a cord from
around his neck. Staff did not want to pull on the cord and risk
having it tighten or cut it and risk cutting Youth A. Staff were
talking with Youth A as he was attempting to put the cord over the
door. When the cord kept falling off the door and Youth A gave up
and staff were able to get the hair straightener from him. All the
other kids were in their bedrooms at the time. After giving up the
cord, Youth A tried to tie a pair of pants around his neck. Youth A
was laughing and running from staff as they tried to remove the
pants. Supervisor 1 could not recall what Youth A was saying, but
remembered staff were encouraging him to be safe and following
him to maintain arm’s length supervision. Youth A then ran out to
the fence and tried to put the pants over the top of the fence.
Supervisor 1 spoke with Youth A and told him they were very
worried he could get hurt, even if he did not intend to. Supervisor
1 explained that if the pants were too tight on his neck, staff may
not be able to remove them in time. Supervisor 1 attempted to
remove the pants from his neck when Youth A began to drop his
weight. Supervisor 1 told Youth A that she was having a hard time
untying them. Youth A immediately stood up and she was able to
untie the item. Youth A was never suspended or hanging. Youth A
was not restrained as staff did not want to risk having him escalate
and get injured.
Supervisor 1 stated that staff are very aware that Youth A needs
to be watched at all times. If Youth A attempts any self-injury, at
least three staff are needed to intervene, due to Youth A being
very tall and strong. In all prior incidents, Youth A would go to the
limit, then stop and allow staff to intervene.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face-to-face on 8/15/24 by DCWL
and MDHHS Worker. Supervisor 2 was present for the incident on
8/9/24. Supervisor 2 was unsure why Youth A was escalated but
observed that he was throwing things. Staff tried to give Youth A
space. But Youth A began looking for things to tie around his
neck. Youth A attempted to put a cord and some pants around his
neck. Staff kept taking items from him, but Youth A moved through
the unit quickly picking up items that belonged to other youth.
When staff tried to remove the item, Youth A would run from staff.
5

If staff were holding the item, they would let go when Youth A
would pull away to avoid having the item tighten. Supervisor 2
called for assistance then the management team arrived. Law
Enforcement was also called. Staff were constantly with Youth A
trying to verbally deescalate him. Youth A was never restrained.
Youth A was swearing and laughing as he ran from staff. Youth A
was never suspended or handing from any object.
On 10/12/24 Youth A returned to the facility. Staff contacted
Supervisor 2 and requested assistance on the unit. When
Supervisor 2 arrived, Youth A was looking for things to put around
his neck. Youth A stood on a counter and tried to wrap the
curtains around his neck. But staff were standing there with him
and cut the curtains down, to prevent him from trying again. Youth
A was taken back to the hospital after that incident.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face on 8/15/24 by DCWL and
MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 was present for the incident on 8/9/24.
Staff 2 reported that Youth A became upset when he had to wait
to make a phone call. Youth A threw her tray of food and began
screaming at staff. Staff 2 stepped out of the area as she seemed
to be the focus of his anger. Youth A could be heard yelling and
throwing furniture. Staff 2 called for assistance from the
management team. Staff attempted to talk with Youth A, but he
walked away and grabbed a blanket and wrapped it around his
neck. A code was called, and the other youth went into their
rooms. Staff were able to remove the blanket from Youth A. Youth
A then grabbed a flat iron from a peer’s cubby and put the cord
around his neck. Staff 2 was able to remove the cord, then
stepped out for a few moments as several other staff were there to
assist. When Staff 2 returned Youth A had pants tied around his
neck and ran outside. Staff were able to remove the blanket.
Throughout the incident, staff were close to Youth A and able to
intervene before he could hang or suspend himself.
Staff have since removed everyone’s belongings from the unit.
They previously had locking cubies, but Youth A broke the locks to
access peers’ belongings. After removing items, staff had to give
youth their belongings as needed, then return them to an area that
Youth A cannot access.
Staff 2 was also on the unit for the incident on 8/13/24. Youth A
tried to put his clothes around his neck, but staff were able to stop
him. Youth A then stood on a counter and put curtains around his
neck. Staff 2 cut the curtains with scissors. Youth A was never
hanging or suspended as he was standing on the counter.
6

Youth A was taken to the hospital after this incident. Staff 2 was at
the hospital and observed that Youth A continued to challenge
hospital staff by trying to put sheets and cords around his neck.
Hospital staff had to restrain Youth A.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed face-to-face on 8/15/24 by DCWL
and MDHHS Worker. Supervisor 3 was present for the incident on
8/9/24, but not for the incident on 8/13/24. Supervisor 3 arrived on
the unit to assist staff. When they arrived, Youth A was yelling that
he did not want to be there. Staff were able to successfully
remove a cord from Youth A’s possession. But Youth A
immediately grabbed a pair of pants and put them around his
neck. Staff were talking to Youth A and walking with him,
encouraging him to remove the pants. Youth A kept running from
staff. Youth A moved quickly through the unit, grabbing items
faster than staff could take them. Supervisor 3 stated that Youth A
was never hanging or suspended. Youth A had staff watching him
at all times.
Foster Care Worker was contacted by video call on 9/12/24.
Foster Care Worker stated that Youth A was adamant about
leaving the facility and would frequently act out. Youth A moved to
a new placement shortly after the alleged incident. Youth A
seemed to be doing well at the new placement and had periods of
stability and periods of acting out when upset.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face on 9/30/24. Youth A
reported he could not recall many details about the incidents on
8/9/24 or 8/13/24. Youth A stated that he did not want to be at that
placement and felt that staff did not do anything to help him leave.
Youth A stated that he, “just wanted to get out of there. I wasn’t
trying to hurt myself”.
Documents reviewed
• 8/9/24 incident reports completed by Supervisor 1,
Supervisor 2, Supervisor 3, Staff 1, and Staff 2 were
reviewed and found to be consistent with information
provided during their interviews.
• Agency policy titled Physical Intervention Policy stated:
o Physically restraining children should be an absolute
last resort.
o Therapeutic Crisis Intervention (TCI) model
emphasizes verbal de-escalation and active listening
skills to defuse crisis situations.
o Restraint is only to be used a) when all other less
intrusive approaches have been attempted
7

unsuccessfully and when there is no time to try other
alternatives. b) To prevent serious injury to the child,
self-injury, or injury to others.
Video reviewed
The incident on 8/9/24 occurred from 5:45pm-6:03pm. There were
four staff in milieu with two youth (Youth A and Youth B). All were
sitting down eating except for Youth A. Youth A could be seen
talking to staff, but there was no audio. Youth A threw staff’s food
tray. Staff got up and walked out. Youth A threw a chair, and a
laundry basket then hit the basket with a broom. Youth A then
picked up Youth B’s bin of personal belongings and put it away in
a cubby. Youth A could be seen yelling at staff. Youth A threw a
chair across the room, flipped over furniture, turned lights off, and
then walked down the hallway. Youth A came back to the area
with staff. Staff in the kitchen were straightening up and moving
peers from the area. Staff were observed trying to talk to Youth A,
but he kept walking away. Youth A appeared agitated and
gesturing with his arms at staff. Youth A dragged a large chair
through the room and tossed it. Youth A walked down the hallway,
then came back, grabbed a blanket off the couch and started
wrapping it around his neck. Youth A went down the hallway, in
view of staff and tried to attach himself to the emergency exit door.
Two additional staff entered the unit. Two staff went down the
hallway. A third staff called for assistance. Third staff then went
down the hallway to assist. A fourth staff went down the hallway. A
fifth staff then went down the hallway. Staff talked with Youth A
and worked at getting the blanket away from him from 5:49-
5:52pm.
Youth A went back to the common area with staff following. Youth
A was throwing food trays and a laundry basket. Two staff are on
the phone, presumably with managers. Youth A went into Youth
B’s cubby of personal belongings, grabbed a flat iron, and put the
cord around his neck. Four staff followed him down the hallway as
he went to the emergency exit door. One staff dropped the blanket
on the couch to go assist. One staff observed straightening
furniture and cleaning up food from the floor and putting laundry
basket in locked closet, then blanket. Two more staff joined at the
exit door, talking to youth and attempting to obtain the hair
straightener. Youth A opened the outside door a few times. Two
staff left the area. Staff were able to remove the cord from youth’s
neck, but he immediately put it back on, several times. Staff
intervened with Youth A regarding the cord from 5:52-5:54PM.
Youth A became physical with staff. Pushed staff into a room off
camera. One staff entered the room, three remained in the
8

hallway. Staff came out of the room; Youth A came out of the
room. Staff tried to take the iron from youth. Youth A laid on the
floor. Staff were able to get the iron out of Youth A’s hands and
secure it. Youth A followed staff back to the main area. Youth A
went in the cubby and got sweatpants out then put them around
his neck. Youth A ran from staff, back down to the emergency exit.
Three staff were present. Youth ran back into the room off
camera. One staff followed. One staff waited in the hallway. Youth
A laid on the floor in the doorway of the room, kicking at staff. Staff
came out of the room. Youth A went back in, as two more staff
arrived to intervene. Youth A then had a shirt in his hands. Youth
A ran at staff aggressively. Staff backed away. Youth A grabbed
another pair of sweatpants and put them around his neck then
walked into another room off camera. Three staff followed. Youth
A came out of the room with pants around his neck, with staff
walking behind him trying to remove them. Staff had their hand
between pants and neck to give space but let go of the pants
when Youth A began to run. Three other staff were present. Youth
A kept running from staff. Three staff followed Youth A to the
emergency door again. Youth A tried to put the pants over the
door. Staff intervened and kept the door open. Staff were able to
get the pants from Youth A. Staff walked back to the common
area with the pants in hand and put them on the couch. Youth
went into a bedroom. Staff were in the hallway. Youth came out
after a while and walked down to the common area, picked pants
up and put them around his neck again. Staff were present and
tried to stop him, but he ran to the door again. Two staff
intervened at the door, then Youth A ran out the door.
Analysis Based on interviews and video review, the agency provided
proper supervision and support when Youth A attempted to self-
harm.
Technical Assistance:
As Youth A moved from one object to another throughout the unit,
it was observed on the video that staff would remove an object
from the youth and set it down, to run and intervene with the youth
again. While it is understandable staff had to move quickly to
intervene, it was noted that several staff were available and one or
two staff could have been tasked with removing objects from the
unit, such as the blanket and peers clothing and personal
belongings, to prevent Youth A from obtaining them.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
